properties.assessment_comment: Numerous spawning sockeye immediately adjacent to culvert outlet and upstream. Channel dry at the time of assessment but appears as though this stream joins with and drains the watershed for the stream mapped as larger located to the east approximately 1km. Floodplain modelling shows this.
properties.link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
properties.assessment_comment_og: Numerous spawning sockeye immediately adjacent to culvert outlet and upstream. Channell dry at the time of assessment, but appears as though this stream joins with and drains the watershed for the stream mapped as larger located to the east approximately 1km. properties.crossing_fix: Replace Structure with Streambed Simulation CBS
properties.assessment_comment: Review of floodplain mapping indicates that this watershed actually drains to 1 km west through an open bottom structure. Adjacent land use is for cattle so this may be affecting drainage and habitat health upstream.
properties.condition_notes: Pipe is rusted all the way through at the top 1m
properties.climate_notes: This cover is not appear to be the main drain for this watershed. Evaluation of floodplain mapping indicates this watershed drains through the larger open bottom of structure located approximately 1 km west.
properties.climate_priority_notes: A sockeye spawning area was identified approximately 1km west and the high-value Nadina River is located just downstream; however, this crossing did not appear to receive significant flow, as indicated by the channel type and size.
properties.link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
properties.assessment_comment_og: Review of flood plane mapping indicates that this watershed actually drains to 1 km West through an open bottom structure. Adjacent land use is for cattle so this may be affecting drainage and habitat health upstream.

properties.crossing_fix: Replace with New Open Bottom Structure
properties.assessment_comment: Larger stream than expected, with substantial flow, a large outlet drop, and a significant outlet pool indicating the culvert is likely undersized for the crossing. Some gravels suitable for bull trout spawning were present.
properties.condition_notes: Some small wood debris blocking the inlet. Large outlet drop and fairly large outlet pool indicate culvert is under size.
properties.climate_notes: Cover appears undersized, however there appears to be a decent buffer distance between here and the likely high value habitat, located downstream in the Nadina river with no infrastructure in between
properties.climate_priority_notes: Fish presence unknown however it is assumed based on the map gradient. Very remote no traffic road.
properties.link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
properties.assessment_comment_og: Larger stream than expected. Go to lots of flow and large outlet drop and fairly large outlet pool indicate this culvert is well undersized for the crossing. Some gravels suitable for BT spawning present.

properties.crossing_fix: Replace with New Open Bottom Structure
properties.assessment_comment: This is the crossing on Colleymount Road; however, two additional pipes located approximately 10m west and just upstream appear to be remnants of pipes under historic Colleymount Road location. The existing pipe was in poor condition, with rust-through observed along the upstream 2m. The stream was dry at the time of assessment.
properties.condition_notes: Culvert in poor shape and rusting through, but no outlet job indicates the pipe is decently sized.
properties.climate_notes: Lack of outlet shop indicates that the pipe is decently sized. Road is protected just upstream by parking blocks that are located at the outlet of the historic pipes just upstream.
properties.climate_priority_notes: Stream flows through Noralee West recreation site. Culvert is located approximately 50m upstream of Francois Lake.  Assumed fish bearing during non-dry times of year due to location adjacent to the lake and low gradient
properties.link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
properties.assessment_comment_og: This is the crossing on CollieyMount Road however there are also two pipes approximately 10 m west and just upstream that are likely historically were within Colleyount Road. Pipe is in poor condition with rust all the way through for the top upstream 2 m. Stream was dry at Time of assessment.

properties.crossing_fix: Replace with New Open Bottom Structure
properties.assessment_comment: This pipe, along with the adjacent overflow pipe, appeared to be located under what was likely the historic alignment of Colleymount Road. Approximately 3–4m downstream of the outlets, the road was armored with parking blocks that directed flow west into the oval culvert beneath the current road. The channel was dry at the time of assessment.

properties.crossing_fix: Replace with New Open Bottom Structure
properties.assessment_comment: Very nice stream with good flow and abundant, small gravel upstream and down. There is a boulder line approximately 3m downstream of the outlet that has removed the outlet drop but creates a ~40cm high cascade. Outlet of culvert is approximately 25m from François lake.
properties.condition_notes: Culvert appears to be getting old but is in decent shape. No outlet drop.
properties.climate_notes: Culvert is 25 m upstream from François Lake
properties.climate_priority_notes: Unpaved road with low traffic volume, but access would likely be difficult or impossible via the ferry if the road were closed.

properties.assessment_comment: Bridge span estimated from photos.

properties.crossing_fix: Replace Structure with Streambed Simulation CBS
properties.assessment_comment: Only photos and downstream width measurements were collected in 2025 due to limited time; all other information was transcribed from the 2024 survey. Habitat confirmations and eDNA samples were collected both upstream and downstream. A large wetland was located approximately 70–80m downstream of the culvert outlet. Abundant gravels were present within the first 20–30m below the outlet pool, where flow was strong, and a substantial outlet drop was observed.
properties.link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
properties.assessment_comments_og:
Very short on time so only photos and downstream widths were gathered in 2025. The rest of the information has been transcribed from the survey done in 2024. Habitat confirmation conducted and EDNA collected downstream and upstream.

Load wetland is located approximately 70 to 80 m downstream of the culvert outlet. Abundant gravel in the first 20 to 30 m below the culvert outlet pool. Huge outlet drop and good flow.

properties.crossing_fix: Replace with New Open Bottom Structure
properties.assessment_comment: Very long culvert in poor condition, with water flowing out through the eroded pipe bottom rather than the outlet, which landed on a dry boulder riprap cascade. Large beaver dams began approximately 50–100m downstream. Habitat confirmation was conducted upstream and downstream of the crossing, as well as at the railway crossing approximately 1.5km downstream near the Fraser River.
properties.link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
properties.assessment_comment_og: Very long cover in poor shape. Outlet land on Boulder rip wrap cascade is currently dry as the water is falling out through the bottom of the eroded pipe. Downstream 50 to 100 m very large beaver dams begin. Habitat confirmation conducted downstream and upstream as well as upstream and downstream of the railway located approximately 1.5 km downstream adjacent to the Fraser river

properties.crossing_fix: Replace with New Open Bottom Structure
properties.assessment_comment: Work was completed in 2019 to backwater the outlet and remove the outlet drop as well as to put baffles within the culvert. Routine monitoring form also filled out a can be found in accompanying report. eDNA collected in 2025 upstream and downstream of this crossing as well as above the railway crossing upstream, see report for results.
properties.condition_notes: No evidence of embankment eroding or damage to repairs conducted in 2019
properties.climate_notes: No infrastructure located downstream and structure appears well
properties.climate_priority_notes: Due to low summer flows, the stream did not appear to provide high habitat value for salmon species, which have been confirmed in the system (CO downstream). Given the size of the system and the extensive fill, culvert replacement would likely require a multi-year effort.
